results.title: Projective generation of conics (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Introduces the eccentricity definition, then focuses on projective definitions devoid of metric notion implying the construction of a conic by straight edge alone. Shows methods of construction developed by Pascal, Malaurin, Braikenridge, Poncelet and Steiner. The logical relationship between the methods is demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota
results.description:

results.title: Journey to the centre of a triangle (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cornwell, Katharine Cornwell and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Examines the incentre, circumcentre, the centroid, and the orthocentre of triangles. Visual constructions illustrate each kind of centre, and several examples are used to show how each is determined. Without narration. For beginning geometry students.

results.title: Dihedral kaleidoscopes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy, International Film Bureau and University of Minnesota
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Presents basic ideas of symmetry by exhibiting dihedral groups by reflections of intersecting mirrors. From reflection in a single mirror the film proceeds to study the surprising effects and beautiful patterns that can be produced with two or three mirrors. Observations on the general case are made as well as on the limiting case in which two mirrors are parallel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Art Landy, International Film Bureau and University of Minnesota
results.description:

results.title: Central similarities (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Jay Hines and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Dilatations (central similarities) are introduced to solve the problem of inscribing an ellipse to touch the sides of a given triangle at their midpoints. Coordinate geometry is also introduced to solve a subsidiary problem stressing the importance of the geometric interpretation of algebraic equations. Narrated by Delbert Ball.

results.title: Central perspectives (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Reviews the definition of range and pencil. Introduces the basic projective transformation, namely the central perspectivity. When the narrator poses the question of the number of points required to uniquely determine a projectivity (product of perspectivity) the viewer is led to the fundamental theorem of projective geometry.

results.title: Dirt Track Racing for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD envelope, install instructions in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Dirt Track Racing, the player controls a vehicle in a race around oval or figure-eight dirt tracks. The game features three classes of cars - stock, pro stock, and late model - which can be enhanced with high performance parts. The game allows you to either play one race or go through a career mode where the player starts with next to nothing and slowly accumulates more money and better cars through winning races and gaining sponsors. The player can also race up to 10 people online.
results.description: In Dirt Track Racing, the player controls a vehicle in a race around oval or figure-eight dirt tracks. The player can also race up to 10 people online.

results.title: Proof (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House and House and Moorhouse Films
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House and House and Moorhouse Films

results.title: Proof
results.creator_credit: Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria and House and Moorhouse Films
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay. Cast also includes Genevieve Picot, Russell Crowe, heather Mitchell, Jeffrey Walker, Saskia Post, Frankie J. Holden.
